course.subject: ECON
course.name: What Applied Microeconomics Tells Us About Our Life and Social Policy
course.description: This course will provide students opportunities to critically read and interpret social science literature on human capital development over the life cycle. It will also give students an opportunity to discuss, through examples, how this evidence could be applied in the real world policy design. The questions to be addressed in this course focus on human capital development such as health, education, and labor policies over the course of one’s life. The examples will help students understand how to interpret available data and use it to evaluate different policy programs.

reviews.author: iloveecon
reviews.title: Good grade CC course
reviews.comment_content:
Topic 1: Fetal Origin Hypothesis - I am pregnant. How do environmental conditions during pregnancy affect my child's life?
Topic 2: Early Childhood Education, Health, and Nutrition - I have a three-year-old son. What are the long-term effects of childhood health and education?
Topic 3: COVID-19 Policies - Is it a good idea to close schools during COVID-19 pandemic? What are the consequences of school closure? How can we booster COVID-19 Vaccination?
Topic 4: Sex Discrimination and Parental Investment - Does Sex Discrimination still exist?
Topic 5: Policy failures - How do policy interventions fail to achieve its goals?
Topic 6: Determinants of a life success -  What are the determinants of life success?
reviews.comment_teaching: I would say his teaching is on average because he is new to hkust and he teaches this course the first time, so certainly there must be some improvements. I love how he combines his personal experience into the topic because it is kind of interesting and make the lesson less boring. Also, his explanation on some critical concepts is good like Randomized controlled trials, Regression-discontinuity design because he provides some daily example which is not so common in ust. Moreover, this course doesn't involve much microeconomics theory behind so if you want to study traditional theories, go to econ 2103 instead and this course mainly focuses on the research findings of different topics like covid-19 which is extremely interesting. I would say this course content is the most interesting and most related to our daily life in ust and it's not just about memorizing facts and calculations. In fact, this course has little or even no calculations at all which suits students with weak mathematical background.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm exam(mean: 72.72, SD:14.92, high:92.5, 30% of the grade)
me: 92.5/100
Final exam(mean: 75.35, SD: 13.44, high:97, 30% of the grade)

Two policy recommendation papers are in total of 20% of the grade

me: 14/15
Class Participation(mean:3.99, high:5, 5% of the grade)
me: 5/5
Final score(mean: 76.01, high: 95.1, me: 95.1/100)
Final grade:A+

Grading is lenient as he said he would be as generous as possible in giving out grades. For the two policy recommendation papers, as long as you have concrete evidence and research paper found, it is okay to get a good mark as the TA is lenient in grading them. Also, the group presentation is lenient as long as you have prepared well and spoke well on that day. Participation marks are easy to get too as long as you have commented something on the chat box in zoom. But I think next semester you guys have to speak out to say something on class since it is most likely to be F2F. So, the battleground lies on midterm and final. The format is in short questions which require you to write something based on your own opinion with supporting evidence. It is closed-book and you have to remember some of the research findings to help you establish your own arguments. But no need to remember the source and data, just some significant findings is okay because he doesn't want us to memorize facts just like other courses in ust. So I appreciate that a lot. Moreover, you do not need to write so many things as there is a harsh time limit and the professor said you only need to write the points with brief elaboration. So just be precise.
reviews.comment_workload: Moderate workload, but it becomes huge when it comes to the two recommendation papers because the deadline of each recommendation paper is set after the day of finishing that topic so you have to start your work when he first teaches that topic. However, for the presentation, it is easy because you only have to combine each of your group mates work into one ppt and present it to other students. For the midterm and final, the paper itself is not hard. Just grab some time to look at the reading materials and ppt because most of the questions are mainly based on them. The reading materials are not so long, only 7-8 pages but with many graphs.

reviews.author: wooyoungk
reviews.title: Definitely consider taking this course
reviews.comment_content:
Topic 1: Fetal Origin Hypothesis - I am pregnant. How do environmental conditions during pregnancy affect my child's life?
Topic 2: Early Childhood Education, Health, and Nutrition - I have a three-year-old son. What are the long-term effects of childhood health and education?
Topic 3: COVID-19 Policies - Is it a good idea to close schools during COVID-19 pandemic? What are the consequences of school closure? How can we booster COVID-19 Vaccination?
Topic 4: Sex Discrimination and Parental Investment - Does Sex Discrimination still exist?
Topic 5: Policy failures - How do policy interventions fail to achieve its goals?
Topic 6: Determinants of a life success -  What are the determinants of life success?

The course content was highly informative and relevant to real-life situations. The course provided valuable insights into how environmental conditions during pregnancy affect a child's life, the long-term effects of childhood health and education, COVID-19 policies, sex discrimination, and policy failures. Additionally, the course discussed the determinants of life success, which was insightful. Overall, the course content was very helpful and relevant to society today.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor's teaching style is engaging and effective. In addition to being quite funny, he is skilled at explaining complex concepts in a clear and concise manner, making the material more accessible to students. His enthusiasm for the subject matter is contagious, and he encourages active participation and discussion in the classroom.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading system for this course is very fair and transparent. Typically, students who perform in the upper quartile of the class receive an A- grade. The professor has consistently emphasized his commitment to generous grading practices throughout the course, and this was evidently reflected in the final letter grades students received.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for this course is manageable with only two policy recommendation papers and a group presentation. There are no additional take-home assignments or homework, allowing students to focus on these main projects. This structure also provides ample time for research, analysis, and collaboration with peers on the group presentation.

reviews.author: Peipar
reviews.comment_content:
1. Fetal Origin Hypothesis (how do environmental factors during pregnancy affect a child's life?)

2. Early Childhood Education, Health and Nutrition (what are the long-term affects of early childhood health and education?)

3. Covid-19 Policies (is school closure a good idea? how can we boost vaccinations?)

4. Sex Discrimination and Parental Investment (does sex discrimination still exist?)

5. Policy Failures (how do policy interventions fail to achieve their goals?)

6. Determinants of Life Success (what determines life success?)

Basically, we looked at different research papers to answer the main questions for each topic. This is not a true economics course, there are no microeconomics or macroeconomics concepts.

Content is quite basic. But there are some good-to-know moments.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He's not boring, doesn't mind questions, and has strong opinions.

Lectures are quite good, usually he will start with some casual conversation like about the weather. Well-paced and lots of opportunities for interaction and opinion sharing. He likes to share about his life experience.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% Policy-recommendation papers (choose any 2/6 topics)
15% Group presentation (1 of the 2 topics chosen above)
30% Midterm (covers topics 1-3)
30% Final (covers topics 4-6)
5% Class participation (zoom chat/canvas discussions)

Midterm and Final are fair grading, and these will basically determine your grade. As the grading is very kind for other areas.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite light.

Policy paper takes some time, but luckily the grading is generous. As long as you can think of a relevant topic and cite a couple research papers, you should be fine. In my experience, even a surface-level analysis is enough for 8 or 9 (out of 10).

Group presentation is easy enough, you can do one big topic or several smaller topics. Similar content to policy paper.

Class participation is easy to get.

For the exams, lecture slides and reading materials are enough as preparation, even if you don't attend all the lectures. Difficulty is well-balanced, it's more about lots of questions not enough time. And it's closed-book. No real need to memorize anything, but a little is useful to cite in your arguments.

reviews.author: Testing1234
reviews.title: A relax course, strongly recommend to use it as CC
reviews.comment_content:
– Topic 1: Pregnancy (Fetal Origin Hypothesis): I am pregnant. How do environmental conditions during pregnancy affect my child's life?
– Topic 2: Early Childhood Policy: I have a three-year-old son. What are the long- term effects of childhood health and education?
– Topic 3: Working Mom and a Role of Father: What are the long-term effects of working-mom on child outcomes
– Topic 4: Friends: How important my friends are in my life?
– Topic 5: Determinants of a life success: What are the determinants of life success?
– Topic 6: Sex Discrimination and Parental Investment: Does Sex Discrimination still exist?
– Topic 7: Policy failures: How do policy interventions fail to achieve its goals?
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Kim loves raising personal experiences, which makes the class more relaxed and chill. He loves interacting with students. You can easily understand the result of those economic papers with his examples. He also loves playing some songs before the 3 hours class. There are also some 15-minute breaks every hour. He tries his best not to make this 3 hours summer course a tough one.
reviews.comment_grading:
Reasonable.

– 2 Policy recommendation papers (20%, 10% each)
– Group Presentation (20%)
– Exam (50%)
– Class participation (10%)

Policy recommendation papers: if you submit something, even though they are nonsense, you get 7/10. The grading for the papers are very generous. The median of the 2 papers are 9 and 10 respectively. I got 9 and 10 for the two papers.

Group Presentation: you will be assigned to a 2 people group according to your topic preference. If you have enough Evidence and Support in your presentation, you will be good. Median 8.75, me 10

Exam: full marks 143, open-ended questions. I strongly recommend you go through the required readings. As long as you understand the lecture slides and the readings, you can get good scores. Median 95.5, UQ108.25, LQ 85, max 128, me 113

Participation: you can get participation scores by answering questions in class or commenting in the discussion board. Median 10, me 10

Overall: A
reviews.comment_workload: Since it is a Summer course, it is a little bit rush for us to prepare the presentation. The group formation was announced 2 days before the first presentation date. I am one of the group that has to present in the first day, so we only have ~1 day to prepare the presentation. Therefore professor said he will be generous with day 1's presentations. In general, the workload is a little bit high as you have to write 2 5 pages papers and a presentation.

reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is on pace and each PowerPoint will be covered in 1-2 lessons so it is easy to catch up. Some personalized viewpoints are shared (especially regarding COVID-19 and the education system) that will come up during the midterms and finals, so the course is quite opinionated towards the professor's beliefs. If you enjoy a casual lecture approach this course is good for you as he often shares his life experiences and past research into each topic.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% Policy-recommendation papers
10% Group presentation
30% Midterm (Topic 1-3)
35% Final (Topic 4-6)
5% Class participation (Canvas discussion with emphasis on replies instead of comments/in-class responses)

Grading is lenient however it is very competitive as the midterms and finals are relatively easy. Both the midterms and finals reflect more on time management than actual understanding (during the finals the professor kept extending the time allocated as he realized students were not able to finish within the set time).
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is minimal for students who are used to writing long essays, group project is usually the biggest issue as there may be freeloaders. However, the essays and presentation only deviate around 1% of the total grade each as it is out of 10 (most students score a 9) so it isn't something to stress about. Midterms and finals do not correlate to each other as they each test on different topics so it is possible to recover from a bad midterm/final, make sure to read the professor's reading materials as he often quizzes the real-life examples he raises on there.

reviews.author: Harrying
reviews.title: Good Grade CC but plan ahead for your work
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction - General introduction of the course

2. Family policy

Topic 1: Fetal Origin Hypothesis - I am pregnant. How do environmental conditions during pregnancy affect my child's life?

Topic 2:  Early Childhood Policy - I have a three-year-old son. What are the long-term effects of childhood health and education?

Topic 3: Working Mom - What are the long-term effects of working-mom on child outcomes

3.  COVID-19 Policy

COVID-19 Policies - Is it a good idea to close schools during COVID-19 pandemic? What are the consequences of school closure? How can we booster COVID-19 Vaccination? Is Zero-COVID policy a good idea?

4. Friend Impacts: How important my friends are in my life?

5. Determinants of a life success -  What are the determinants of life success?

6. Sex Discrimination and Parental Investment - Does Sex Discrimination still exist?

7. Policy failures -  How do policy interventions fail to achieve its goals

Some of the chapters are quite interesting but some are rather boring. All you need to know is how you can interpret the graphs and recite some key terms like causal inference

There are also assigned readings for each chapter. Bryan will pick some graphs from the required reading as exam questions. It should be fairly easy to understand even without lectures. I would say you can skip all the classes if you don't give a shit on attendance points. (The recordings are of really bad quality. The recordings cannot precisely capture his voice.)

The coursework is like the elementary level of Econ 3334 but without all the maths and derivation. It just asks you for the intuition or the logic of causal inference. (Correlation Vs Causal) And the exam questions are really easy!!

To be honest the first 5 topics they are quite good, however, the 6th topic becomes very weird. The topic is about determinants of life success, but what he mentioned in the last is life is 80% determined by luck. Hmm, very weird. Once I though life success can be determined by wealth, education, gender and socioeconomic status.

Btw, professor, could you please kindly change your password for your exam paper? Only 8 digit number based on dates is not strong enough! I think there already has some people who accessed the final exams file early and it's not fair.

However, the professor didn't attend his office hour on time for once. Also, when he changed the zoom link, he did not announced it. I think professor could handle these things better.

Finally, this is a new course, therefore he would like to listen to our opinion. Including asking for SFQ opinions and let us to choose the best 3 topics. I think it's very good, especially for a brand new course.

Overall, I think his teaching is not very bad, not perfect though, so I would give his teaching a B.
